Both works also contain the stories of Cleobis and Biton, Trophonius and Agamedes, Silenus Midas, and the Terinean Elysius. I may add that Plut. also notices the death ol Theramenes, p. 105 b.

The quotation from Callimachus Tusa Disp. i §93 is given in Plutarch without mention of Callimachus (c. 24) μεῖον γὰρ ὄντως Τρωίλος ἐδάκρυσεν ἢ Πρίαμος. Heine thinks that Crantor (who was dead by ²70 ne.) can scarcely have quoted Callimachus (who died about 240 nc). He thinks that Cicero and Plutarch hada later source in common. The epigram ol Callimachus upon Cleombrotus quoted by Cic. 1 5 84, is not in Plutarch, but Heine thinks that it was probably in their common source. Corssen³ thought that Posidonius was the source for all the matter contained in the first book of the Tusculan Disputations. In that case Cicero might have found Callimachus’ epigram in Posidonius. But Heine seems right in finding it improbable that Posidonius should have copied a work so well known and so widely read in his day as that ol Crantor, and in laying stress on the lact that Plutarch always refers to Crantor, and not to Posidonius, as his source.
